chapter: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Patient diagnosed with chronic suppurative otitis media has been planned for Tympanoplasty. All among the following are landmarks to identify the commonly injured nerve during this procedure except
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Posterior belly of digastric Explanation: Tympanoplasty is a surgery of middle ear, commonly injured nerve during middle ear surgery is Facial nerve . Oval window, Processus cochleariformis and short process of incus are related to facial nerve in middle ear, while posterior belly of digastric is a landmark of facial nerve in parotid surgeries. Surgical landmarks of facial nerve: MIDDLE EAR AND MASTOID: 1) Processus Cochleariformis (Option C) tympanic segment of nerve starts at this level 2) Oval Window & Horizontal Canal (Option A) runs superior to the oval window (stapes) and inferior to the horizontal canal 3) Short Process of Incus (Option D) medial to the short process of incus at the aditus 4) Pyramid passes behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus 5) Digastric ridge nerve exits the mastoid at the anterior end of the digastric ridge. PAROTID: 1) Cartilaginous Pointer located 1 cm deep, slightly anterior and inferior to this triangular cartilage 2) Tympanomastoid Suture lies 6-8 mm deep to the suture 3) Styloid Process crosses lateral to the styloid process 4) Posterior Belly of Digastric (Option B) between the styloid process and posterior belly of the digastric muscle Note: Digastric ridge is a facial nerve landmark of middle ear, while digastric muscle is related to parotid.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the development of ear ossicles and inner ear is false?

options.A: Malleus and incus are developed from first pharyngeal arch
options.B: Stapes footplate is developed from otic capsule
options.D: A part of the stapes develops from the third pharyngeal arch

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) A part of the stapes develops from the third pharyngeal arch Explanation: Parts of the stapes except the footplate and annular ligament develop from the second pharyngeal arch, not the third. Development of ear ossicles: Ossicle Embryonic Source Malleus Mesoderm of the first pharyngeal arch Incus Mesoderm of the first pharyngeal arch Stapes Footplate and annular ligament of stapes-Otic capsule Rest-Second pharyngeal arch Inner ear development: Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 8th edition, page 15
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Match the layers of tympanic membrane to the germinal layer from which it developes. Layers of tympanum Germinal layer a.Epithelial layer 1.Ectoderm
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) a1,b3,c2 Explanation: Development of tympanic membrane: Ectoderm → Outer epithelial layer Mesoderm → Middle fibrous layer Endoderm → Inner mucosal layer Development of middle ear:
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Which of the following structures pass through the internal auditory canal?

options.A: Facial nerve, cochlear nerve, and trigeminal nerve
options.B: Cochlear nerve, vestibular nerve, and facial nerve
options.C: Optic nerve, oculomotor nerve, and facial nerve
options.D: Glossopharyngeal nerve, vagus nerve, and accessory nerve

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cochlear nerve, vestibular nerve, and facial nerve Explanation: Internal Auditory Canal (IAC): Lies in temporal bone and exists between the inner ear and posterior cranial fossa. Contents: Facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) - anterosuperior quadrant Cochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII) Vestibular nerve (cranial nerve VIII - Cochlear nerve, Vestibular nerve superior and Inferior) Labyrinthine artery Vestibular ganglion Begins in the temporal bone at an oval shaped opening called the Porus acusticus internus. The canal runs through the petrous segment of the temporal bone,which is lined by dura and filled with spinal fluid. The canal is on average 8.5mm in length and about 4mm in diameter. Divided into superior and inferior segments by the transverse crest/falciform crest. Superior half is further divided into anterior and inferior segments by Bill’s bar/Vertical crest. Posterior portion of the fundus is filled with macula cristal. Labyrinthine artery/Internal auditory artery enters IAC medially in the anteroinferior segment of Porus acusticus internus and courses between facial and cochlear nerve.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with progressive right-sided hearing loss, intermittent tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness. An audiogram shows significant sensorineural hearing loss. Which structure is most likely affected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Organ of Corti Explanation: Organ of Corti is located in the cochlea. It is the primary structure responsible for converting sound vibrations into nerve impulses. Thus damage here leads to sensorineural hearing loss , which aligns with the patient's symptoms and audiogram findings. Important Components of Organ of Corti: Tunnel of Corti: Formed by inner and outer rods and contains cortilymph. Hair cells: Important receptor cells of hearing and transduce sound energy into electrical energy. Inner hair cells Outer hair cells Total count and Rows 3500 and 1 row 12,000 and 3-4 rows Shape Flask shaped Cylindrical shape Nerve supply Mainly afferent Mainfly efferent Function Transmit auditory stimuli More resistant Modulate function of inner hair cells. Easily damaged by ototoxic drugs and high-intensity noise Supporting cells/Deiters cells: Situated between the Outer hair cells and provide support to the latter. Cells of hensen lie outside deiters cells. Tectorial membrane: Consists of gelatinous matrix with delicate fibres. Over lies organ of Corti Malleus (Option A): Ossicles in the middle ear that transmits sound from the tympanic membrane to the inner ear. Issues with the malleus would lead to conductive hearing loss, not the sensorineural hearing loss seen in this patient. Eustachian tube (Option B): Dysfunction can cause middle ear effusions and conductive hearing loss, but it is unlikely to cause the sensorineural hearing loss observed in this patient. Semicircular canals (Option D): Disorders of these structures typically cause vertigo rather than hearing loss. They are not the likely cause of the hearing symptoms described.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly identifies the primary ionic components of endolymph and perilymph in the cochlea?

options.A: Endolymph is high in sodium (Na+), and perilymph is high in potassium (K+).
options.B: Endolymph is high in potassium (K+), and perilymph is high in sodium (Na+).
options.C: Both endolymph and perilymph are high in sodium (Na+).
options.D: Both endolymph and perilymph are high in potassium (K+).

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Endolymph is high in potassium (K+), and perilymph is high in sodium (Na+). extracellular fluid and is rich in sodium ions (Na+). Location: Fills the space between the bony and membranous labyrinth. Communication: Connects with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) through the aqueduct of cochlea. Endolymph: Fills the membranous labyrinth, resembling intracellular fluid with high potassium ions (K+). Secreted by secretory cells of the stria vascularis of the cochlea and by the dark cells. There are two views regarding its flow: Longitudinal , i.e. endolymph from the cochlea reaches saccule, utricle and endolymphatic duct and gets absorbed through endolymphatic sac, which lies in the subdural space, and Radial, i.e. endolymph is secreted by stria vascularis and also gets absorbed by the stria vascularis. This view presumes that endolymphatic sac is a vestigial structure in man and plays no part in endolymph absorption. Composition: Sodium Potassium Endolymph 5 144 Perilymph 140 10
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: In the cochlea, high-frequency sounds are primarily detected at which location along the basilar membrane?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Base of the cochlea Explanation: The length of the basilar membrane increases as we proceed from basal coil to apical coil. Therefore, higher frequencies are heard at basal coil while lower ones are heard at apical coil. Example : Menieres disease early stage affects apex of cochlea and hence low freq hearing loss seen(upsloping audiogram).Later stages show a high freq hearing loss (downsloping) Cochlea: Part of bony labyrinth making 2.5-2.75 turns around central pyramid of bone called modiolus. Around the modiolus and winding spirally like a thread of screw is thin plate of bone called osseous spiral lamina. Bony cochlea contains three compartments: Scala Vestibuli: The uppermost chamber of the cochlea filled with perilymph fluid and begins at the oval window where sound vibrations enter from the middle ear. Scala Media (Cochlear Duct): The middle chamber of the cochlea filled with endolymph fluid and houses the organ of Corti, which contains the hair cells responsible for converting sound vibrations into electrical signals. Three walls of cochlear duct are formed by: Basilar Membrane Reissner's Membrane Stria vascularis: Contains vascular epithelium concerned with secretion of endolymph. Scala Tympani: The lowermost chamber of the cochlea, filled with perilymph fluid and ends at the round window, where sound waves dissipate. Helicotrema: The apex of the cochlea where the scala vestibuli and scala tympani meet and allows the passage of perilymph fluid between these two chambers. The scala tympani is connected with the subarachnoid space through the aqueduct of cochlea. Apex of the cochlea (Option A): The apex of the cochlea is where the basilar membrane is wider and more flexible. It primarily detects low-frequency sounds, not high-frequency sounds. Middle of the cochlea (Option C): The middle portion of the cochlea detects mid-range frequencies. While it plays a role in sound detection, it is not responsible for high-frequency sounds. Near the helicotrema (Option D): The helicotrema is the part of the cochlear apex where the scala tympani and scala vestibuli meet. This region is involved in detecting very low-frequency sounds, not high-frequency ones.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Which of the following accurately describes the anatomy and function of the semicircular canals? The lateral, posterior, and superior canals are oriented perpendicular to each other. Each semicircular canal has an ampullated end that contains the crista ampullaris, which detects angular acceleration. The membranous ducts within the bony canals are filled with perilymph and surrounded by endolymph. The crus commune is formed by the non-ampullated ends of the posterior and superior canals and opens into the vestibule. The semicircular canals are located within the bony labyrinth in the frontal bone.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1,2,4 Explanation: Semicircular canals Location Within the bony labyrinth in the temporal bone.(statement 5 ruled out ) Function The semicircular canals aid in balance and spatial orientation. Canals and Planes 3 Canals: Lateral Canal; Posterior Canal; Superior Canal Each canal is perpendicular to each other. (statement 1) Three canals open into the vestibule through five openings. Fluids Membranous semicircular ducts are inside the bony semicircular canals Membranous semicircular ducts are filled with endolymph and surrounded by perilymph (statement 3 ruled out ) Ampullae and Crus Commune Each canal has an ampullated end, a wider portion containing a sensory structure called the crista ampullaris. (statement 2) Detect angular acceleration (head rotation): Cristae ampullaris contain hair cells that sense endolymph movement and send balance signals to the brain. The non-ampullated ends of the posterior and superior canals merge to form a common channel called the crus commune before entering the vestibule. (statement 4)
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Which structure in the vestibule of the inner ear contains the structure involved in detecting linear acceleration and deceleration.?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Spherical recess Explanation The spherical recess houses the saccule, which detects linear acceleration, but not the utricle. Parts of the Inner Ear The inner ear, or labyrinth, is essential for hearing and balance and is located within the temporal bone. It consists of the bony labyrinth and the membranous labyrinth. Bony Labyrinth A rigid structure filled with perilymph (a sodium-rich fluid), it has three main parts: Vestibule : Central part connecting to the cochlea and semicircular canals. Bony Recesses in the vestibule contains the utricle and saccule (part of the membranous labyrinth). Spherical Recess: Contains the saccule, a membranous sac involved in detecting linear acceleration and deceleration. Elliptical Recess: Contains the utricle, which works with the saccule to aid in balance and spatial orientation. Oval Window: Located on the vestibule’s lateral wall, it connects to the middle ear. Openings of the Semicircular Canals: The three semicircular canals (lateral, posterior, and superior) have five openings into the vestibule, enabling detection of head rotations. Opening of the Vestibular Aqueduct: Positioned below the elliptical recess, it allows the passage of the endolymphatic duct, which carries endolymph within the membranous labyrinth. Semicircular Canals: Three canals (lateral, posterior, and superior) positioned at right angles to detect rotational head movement. Each has an ampulla containing the crista ampullaris for sensory function. Cochlea: A spiral structure essential for hearing, divided into three chambers (scala vestibuli, scala tympani, and scala media). The scala vestibuli and tympani contain perilymph and communicate via the helicotrema, while the scala media houses the organ of Corti, which converts sound vibrations into electrical signals. Membranous Labyrinth A delicate system within the bony labyrinth, filled with potassium-rich endolymph, it includes: Cochlear Duct (Scala Media): Inside the cochlea, it separates the scala vestibuli and scala tympani and contains the organ of Corti for hearing. Utricle and Saccule: Membranous sacs in the vestibule responsible for detecting linear acceleration and balance. They are connected via the utriculosaccular duct. Semicircular Ducts: Membranous ducts within the bony semicircular canals, contributing to balance. Endolymphatic Duct and Sac: Extending from the utricle and saccule, the duct ends in the endolymphatic sac, important in surgical treatments for conditions like Ménière's disease. Vestibular aqueduct (Option B): The vestibular aqueduct transmits the endolymphatic duct but does not house the utricle or saccule. Semicircular canals (Option C): The semicircular canals detect rotational head movements but do not contain the utricle or saccule.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient is undergoing a mastoidectomy for chronic mastoiditis. During surgery, the surgeon encounters a structure that obstructs access to the deeper petrosal air cells. What is the most likely anatomical structure causing this surgical challenge?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Korner's septum Explanation Complete removal of Korner's septum is crucial to access deeper petrosal cells and eliminate diseased tissue during mastoidectomy. Korner's septum Korner's septum is a bony plate in the mastoid, separating the superficial squamosal air cells from the deeper petrosal air cells. It is a remnant of the developmental petrosquamous suture. Surgical Importance During Mastoidectomy: Korner's septum is important when removing infected mastoid air cells. Challenges in Locating the Antrum: A prominent Korner's septum can block access to the mastoid antrum, complicating surgery. Incomplete Disease Removal: If Korner's septum is not fully removed, deeper infected air cells may be missed, leading to persistent or recurrent infection. Sigmoid sinus (Option A): The sigmoid sinus is located posterior to the mastoid antrum, but it does not directly obstruct access to the deeper air cells during mastoidectomy. Facial nerve (Option B): While the facial nerve is an important structure to avoid during mastoid surgery, it does not form obstruction to the deeper mastoid air cells. Tegmen tympani (Option D): The tegmen tympani forms the roof of the middle ear cavity and does not obstruct the deeper mastoid air cells.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Which of the following describes the posterior boundary of MacEwen's triangle?

options.B: Posterosuperior part of the bony external auditory canal
options.C: A tangent line drawn from the external auditory canal

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) A tangent line drawn from the external auditory canal Explanation MacEwen's Triangle (Suprameatal Triangle) MacEwen's triangle is a key surgical landmark for identifying the mastoid antrum during mastoid surgery. It is located on the mastoid process, the bony prominence behind the ear. The triangle represents the lateral wall of the mastoid antrum. Clinical importance of Macewen triangle: the antrum lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to the triangle. It is an important landmark to locate the mastoid antrum in mastoid surgery. At birth, the lateral antral wall is about 2 mm thick and thickens by 1 mm per year, reaching 12-15 mm in adulthood. The supramastoid crest corresponds to the floor of the middle cranial fossa. Boundaries of MacEwen's Triangle Superiorly : Temporal line (supramastoid crest) Anteriorly : Posterosuperior part of the bony external auditory canal Posteriorly : A tangent line drawn from the external auditory canal (Option C)
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Label the contents of middle ear appropriately

options.A: a-Incus, b-Stapedius, c-Stapes , d-Tensor tympani, e-Malleus
options.B: a-Incus, b-Stapes, c-Stapedius , d-Tensor tympani, e-Malleus
options.C: a-Incus, b-Tensor tympani, c-Stapes , d-Stapedius, e-Malleus
options.D: a-Malleus, b-Stapedius, c-Stapes , d-Tensor tympani, e- Incus

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) a-Incus, b-Stapedius, c-Stapes , d-Tensor tympani, e-Malleus Explanation Middle Ear The middle ear is an air-filled cavity extending from the tympanic membrane, including the eustachian tube, aditus, antrum, and mastoid air cells (collectively called the middle ear cleft). Walls of the Middle Ear (Six-Sided Box) Roof (Tegmen Tympani): Thin bone separating the tympanic cavity from the middle cranial fossa, extending to form the roof of the aditus and antrum. Floor : Thin bone separating the tympanic cavity from the jugular bulb, sometimes deficient leading to jugular bulb projection. Anterior Wall : Thin bone between the cavity and internal carotid artery; contains openings for the eustachian tube and tensor tympani muscle. Posterior Wall: Features the pyramid (stapedius tendon), aditus (connecting attic and antrum), and facial nerve. Medial Wall: Formed by the labyrinth, includes the promontory (cochlea bulge), oval and round windows, facial nerve canal, lateral semicircular canal prominence, and sinus tympani. Lateral Wall: Primarily the tympanic membrane,
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Which structure, located in the petrous part of the temporal bone, is responsible for transmitting the facial nerve (VII) and is commonly involved in pathological conditions such as acoustic neuroma affecting the cerebellopontine angle?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Internal auditory canal Explanation : The internal auditory canal , located in the petrous part of the temporal bone, transmits both the facial nerve (VII) and the vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII). Pathological conditions like acoustic neuroma, which arises from the vestibular division of the vestibulocochlear nerve, commonly affect this canal and extend into the cerebellopontine angle, leading to symptoms involving both hearing and facial nerve function. Anatomy of the Temporal Bone Segments 1. Tympanic : Forms the external auditory canal (EAC). 2. Mastoid: Contains the mastoid air cell system, which is essential for ventilation and drainage of the middle ear. Includes the antrum, connected to the epitympanum, and surrounded by air cells. 3. Petrous : Most medial part, containing the cochlea, vestibule, semicircular canals and internal auditory canal. Houses the facial nerve (VII) and vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII). 4. Squamous : Flat part of the temporal bone that contributes to the lateral skull wall, providing attachment points for muscles and ligaments. Important associated Structures Cranial Nerves: Facial nerve (VII) and Vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII) passes through the internal auditory canal 9th, 10th, and 11th cranial nerves (glossopharyngeal, vagus, accessory) run through the jugular foramen. Vascular Structures : Jugular bulb and carotid artery run near the petrous portion, making the temporal bone a critical area for surgical considerations. Labyrinthine artery passes through the internal auditory canal Internal Jugular Veins make their way out of the cranium and terminate at the subclavian veins via jugular foramen. Other structures: Internal auditory canal, cochlea, vestibule, semicircular canals, vestibular aqueduct, endolymphatic sac . Tegmen tympani (Option A): The tegmen tympani forms the roof of the tympanic cavity but does not transmit the facial nerve. It separates the tympanic cavity from the middle cranial fossa. Stylomastoid foramen (Option B): The stylomastoid foramen is the exit point for the facial nerve from the skull but is not involved in transmitting the facial nerve within the temporal bone. Jugular foramen (Option D): The jugular foramen transmits the glossopharyngeal, vagus, and accessory nerves, but not the facial nerve.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Patient underwent surgery for cholesteatoma 1 year back, now has presented with similar complaints again. Which among the following is the most common site of residual cholesteatoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sinus tympani Explanation: Cholesteatoma is a benign keratinizing epithelial lined cystic structure found in the middle ear and mastoid. Most common site of residual/recurrent cholesteatoma is Sinus tympani - present in medial wall of middle ear. Sinus tympani is a recess bounded superiorly by Ponticulus and inferiorly by subiculum. Structures related to medial wall of middle ear: (1) Promontory, (2) processus cochleariformis, (3) CN VII, (4) oval window, (5) horizontal canal, (6) pyramid, (7) ponticulus, (8) sinus tympani, (9) subiculum, (10) round window, (11) tympanic plexus. Promontory Bulge caused by the basal coil of the cochlea. Oval Window Footplate of the stapes is attached Located below the facial nerve canal Round Window (Fenestra Cochleae) Covered by the secondary tympanic membrane. Canal for Facial Nerve Located above the oval window Nerve may be exposed due to dehiscence Prominence of Lateral Semicircular Canal Located above the canal for the facial nerve Processus Cochleariformis Hook-like projection anterior to the oval window Landmark for tensor tympani tendon attachment First genu of the facial nerve Sinus Tympani (Option B) Deep recess medial to the pyramid Bounded by the subiculum (below) and ponticulus (above) Most common site for residual/recurrent cholesteatoma. Facial recess Bounded by vertical segment of facial nerve, chorda tympani and fossa incudis. Surgical landmark for posterior tympanotomy.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: A 6-year old child was brought to clinic with recurrent episodes of upper respiratory tract infection. Child also complains of earache during this episodes. Doctor suspects that a structure exiting from anterior wall in middle ear is responsible for his earache. Arrange the following structures in order related to the wall (superior-to-inferior) 1) Internal carotid artery 2) Pharyngo-tympanic tube 3) Tensor tympani
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 3-2-1 Explanation: Recurrent upper respiratory tract infections can lead to eustachian tube (Pharyngo-tympanic tube) block. Eustchian tube exits middle ear cavity via the anterior wall. Structures present in anterior wall from above below (superior-to-inferior): 1) Supratubal recess Superior most, present in anterior epitympanum 2) Canal of Tensor tympani (Statement-3) Tensor tympani subsequently runs along the medial wall 3) Pharyngo-tympanic tube (Statement-2) Present in middle 3rd, 5x4mm diameter opening 4) Internal carotid artery (Statement-1) Present in lower 3rd, bony plate covers the artery
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Which among the following are components of the middle ear cleft? 1) Tympanic plexus 2) Stapedius muscle 3) Mastoid air cells 4) Eustachian tube
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1,2,3,4 Explanation: Components of middle ear cleft: Middle ear cavity and its contents: Ear ossicles (Malleus, Incus & Stapes), Tensor tympani muscle, Stapedius muscle (Statement-2) , Tympanic plexus (Statement-1) (It lies on the promontory and is formed by (i) tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal and (ii) sympathetic fibres from the plexus round the internal carotid artery), Chorda tympani nerve. Medial wall of middle ear: (1) Promontory; (2) processus cochleariformis (3)CN VII (4) oval window; (6) horizontal canal (6) pyramid; (7) ponticulus; (8) sinus tympani; (9) subiculum; (10) round window (11 )tympanic plexus Mastoid air cell system (Statement-3) including aditus and antrum Eustachian tube (Statement-4) Functions of middle ear cleft: Ear ossicles: Transfer low-impedance airborne sounds to higher impedance inner ear fluid. Eustachian tube : Exchange of gases, acts as pressure equaliser. Mastoid air cells: protects middle and inner ear from trauma.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: A 50-year-old woman presents with a traumatic perforation of the tympanic membrane. The image is given below. What type of perforation is this?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Attic Explanation: The image shows perforation in the pars flaccida - attic perforation The attic and posterosuperior marginal perforation are seen in dangerous types of CSOM and are often associated with a cholesteatoma. Stratified squamous epithelium from the external auditory canal can grow into the middle ear in any type of marginal perforation by immigration and form a cholesteatoma . Therefore, all marginal perforations are considered dangerous. Central perforations are considered safe as cholesteatomas are usually not associated with them. It is seen in tubotympanic CSOM.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false?

options.A: Pars tensa forms the majority of the tympanic membrane
options.B: Umbo is central part of pars tensa

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) None of the above Explanation: All of the statements are true Pars Tensa Forms most of the tympanic membrane. (Option A) Annulus Tympanicus - Thickened fibrocartilaginous ring at the periphery that fits into the tympanic sulcus. Umbo - Central part of pars tensa (Option B) , tented inward at the tip of the malleus. Cone of Light - Bright reflection radiating from the tip of the malleus to the periphery in the anteroinferior quadrant. Pars Flaccida (Shrapnell’s Membrane) (Option C) Located above the lateral process of the malleus, between the notch of Rivinus and the malleal folds. Less taut and may appear slightly pinkish. Layers of Tympanic Membrane: Outer Epithelial Layer Continuous with the skin lining the external auditory meatus. Inner Mucosal Layer Continuous with the mucosa of the middle ear. Middle Fibrous Layer Contains radial, circular, and parabolic fibers and encloses the handle of the malleus. In Pars Flaccida - Thin and not organized into distinct fibers as seen in pars tensa.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Which of the following statements on tympanic membrane is false?

options.A: Partition between the external acoustic canal and the middle ear.
options.B: The posterosuperior part is more medial than the anteroinferior part.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The posterosuperior part is more medial than the anteroinferior part. Partition between the external acoustic canal and the middle ear. It is Obliquely set and as a result its posterosuperior part is more lateral than the anteroinferior part because TM is present at an angle of 55 degrees with horizontal. Dimensions: Height: 9–10 mm Width: 8–9 mm Thickness: 0.1 mm. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 8th edition, page 3
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: Match the parts of the external ear with the corresponding nerve supply Part Nerve supply a.Lower half of medial and lateral surface of pinna 1.Auricular branch of vagus nerve b.Retroauricular groove of the pinna 2.Facial nerve c.Floor of external auditory canal 3.Greater auricular nerve
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) a3,b2,c1 Explanation: Nerve supply of pinna: Part Nerve supply Most of the medial surface of pinna- lower half and posterior part of the lateral surface Greater auricular nerve (C2,3) Upper part of the medial surface Lesser occipital nerve (C2) Tragus, crus of helix, and adjacent part of the helix Auriculotemporal nerve (V3) Concha and corresponding eminence on the medial surface Auricular branch of vagus (CN X, Arnold’s nerve) Concha and retroauricular groove Facial nerve (CN VII) distributed with fibers of auricular branch of vagus Nerve supply of External Auditory Canal: Part Nerve supply Anterior wall and roof Auriculotemporal nerve (V3) Posterior wall and floor Auricular branch of vagus (CN X) Posterior wall (additional supply) Sensory fibers of facial nerve (CN VII) through auricular branch of vagus Nerve supply of tympanic membrane : Part Nerve supply Anterior half of lateral surface auriculotemporal (V3) Posterior half of lateral surface auricular branch of vagus (CN X). Medial surface tympanic branch of CN IX (Jacobson’s nerve)
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: A 3 year old child presents with swelling and pain in the region of the parotid gland, accompanied by ear discharge. Examination of the external auditory canal (EAC) reveals signs of infection. Which bony anatomical structure is responsible for the spread of infection between the EAC and the parotid gland?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Foramen of Huschke Explanation: Foramen of Huschke: A deficiency in the anteroinferior bony EAC, present in some children under four and occasionally into adulthood. It allows infection to spread between the parotid gland and the EAC. (Option B) Fissures of Santorini: Two gaps in the cartilage of the outer EAC that allow infection to pass between the parotid glands and the EAC. Isthmus: A narrowing in the bony EAC, about 6 mm lateral to the tympanic membrane. It is not an opening but a constriction in the canal. (Option C) Tympanic membrane (Option D) : The tympanic membrane separates the external ear from the middle ear and is not involved in spreading infections to the parotid gland. Mastoid Air Cells (Option A) : Mastoid air cells are a series of air-filled spaces located within the mastoid process of the temporal bone, adjacent to the middle ear. While infections in the middle ear (otitis media) can spread to the mastoid air cells (causing mastoiditis), they do not directly connect the EAC to the parotid gland. Thus, they are not responsible for the spread of infection between these two areas.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: A 10 year old boy presents with ear pain, swelling and redness around the ear. On examination, the external auditory canal is inflamed and furuncles are visible. What part of the external auditory canal is most likely affected?

options.A: Bony part of the external auditory canal
options.C: Cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal Explanation: Furuncles commonly form in the outer third of the canal, which is the cartilaginous portion containing hair follicles and ceruminous glands, making it prone to infections. External auditory canal Connects outer ear to middle ear, from the concha to the tympanic membrane (eardrum). Length & Shape: Approximately 24 mm long (posterior wall). Outer part angles upwards, backwards, and medially. Inner part angles downwards, forwards, and medially. Pinna must be pulled upwards, backwards, and laterally to view the eardrum. Parts Cartilaginous Part (Outer third, approximately 8 mm): Continuous with pinna cartilage. Fissures of Santorini allow infection to spread. Thick skin with ceruminous glands and hair follicles. Furuncles form here. (Option C) Bony Part (Inner two-thirds, approximately 16 mm): Thin skin extends over the tympanic membrane. No hair or ceruminous glands. Isthmus makes foreign body removal difficult. Anterior recess collects debris in infections. Foramen of Huschke (in children) allows infection to spread. Relations Superior: Middle cranial fossa Posterior: Mastoid air cells, facial nerve Inferior: Parotid gland Anterior: Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) Bony part of the external auditory canal (Option A): The bony part of the canal lacks hair follicles and ceruminous glands, which are necessary for furuncle formation. Tympanic membrane (Option B): The tympanic membrane is part of the middle ear and does not have structures like hair follicles that lead to furuncle formation in the external auditory canal. Mastoid air cells (Option D): The mastoid air cells are located posterior to the ear and are not directly involved in the external auditory canal's inflammation or furuncle formation.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear

questions.question: In reconstructive surgical procedures for nasal bridge deformities, if septal cartilage is unavailable, which part of the external ear is most commonly used as an alternative source for cartilage grafts?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Conchal cartilage Explanation : Conchal cartilage is commonly harvested for reconstructive procedures, especially for correcting nasal bridge deformities due to its structural properties if septal cartilage is unavailable. Auricle (Pinna) Structure : Visible part of the ear, composed of yellow elastic cartilage covered by skin, except for the lobule and outer EAC. The skin on the outer surface adheres tightly to the perichondrium; on the inner surface, it is slightly looser. Contains elevations and depressions; the incisura terminalis (between the tragus and helix) lacks cartilage, aiding in surgical access to the EAC and mastoid. (Option C) Surgical Importance: The pinna provides graft materials for reconstructive surgeries, especially in the middle ear. Cartilage and perichondrium from the tragus or concha. (Option B) Fat from the lobule. (Option A) Conchal cartilage can be used to correct nasal bridge deformities. (Option D) Composite grafts of skin and cartilage from the pinna are used for nasal ala repairs. Incisura terminalis- Area where there is no cartilage between the tragus and crus of the helix. An incision (lempert incision) will not cut through the cartilage if made here. Used for endaural approach in surgery of the external auditory canal or of the mastoid.
questions.chapter_heading: Ear-Anatomy Of External Middle And Internal Ear
